clusters.summary: The 2014 FIFA World Cup is still in its opening round, but the soccer tourney has already broken the previous global record for online-video streaming and set new digital high-water marks for ESPN.... In this episode of the Akamai Security Podcast, Bill Brenner talks to CSIRT researcher, Mike Kun, about the latest threats his team is monitoring, including online extortion attempts and possible disruptions during the World Cup. "The 2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil was the largest live sporting event ever delivered in the history of Akamai Technologies, a provider of cloud services." Live online video streaming traffic of the coverage peaked at 8.7 Tbps, setting a new record for the largest single live news event that we have delivered. The event was one of the most watch live broadcasts that Akamai has delivered, passing the 2010 World Cup, Royal Wedding in 2011, and last year's U.S. [Spanish] The 2014 World Cup was one of the most important sporting events in the world.
messages: Did you watch the GRAMMY Awards last month? We helped The Recording Academy successfully deliver the evening’s online GRAMMY Live coverage while meeting its goal of live streaming the video at higher quality than ever before. Read more: http://akamai.me/2mJeaGq. Timeline Photos.

Where were you watching today’s Presidential Inauguration? Live online video streaming traffic of the coverage peaked at 8.7 Tbps, setting a new record for the largest single live news event that we have delivered. Click here to learn more: http://akamai.me/2iKZ6tm. Timeline Photos.

With a peak of 7.5 Tbps and 3.35 million concurrent viewers, last night’s Presidential Election 2016 coverage beat out the peak of this summer’s Euro final. It’s now the largest single news event we have streamed for our customers. Check it out: http://akamai.me/2fD4bj9. Timeline Photos.

The results are in. Last night’s 2016 Presidential Election was the largest single news event Akamai has ever delivered with a peak of 7.5 Tbps and 3.35 million concurrent viewers. Learn more here: http://akamai.me/2eUkrL8. Timeline Photos.

Live video streaming traffic peaked at 3.6 Tbps during Sunday's presidential debate. This is just above the 3.5 Tbps peak we recorded during the Sochi games just two years ago. Our Director of Industry Marketing, Media and Entertainment, Shane Keats, shares his analysis here: http://akamai.me/2eo6zfi. Timeline Photos.

Live video streaming traffic from last night’s Presidential debate peaked at 4.4 Tbps on the Akamai platform, nearing the Rio games’ highest single event peak of 4.5 Tbps during the women’s team gymnastics final. Where did you watch last night’s debate? Timeline Photos.

That’s a wrap! So where did we end up? As of Saturday we delivered more video data for Rio than for the 2014 World Cup, making this summer’s games the largest live sporting event that we have ever helped deliver. Learn more in CableFax: http://akamai.me/2bOWipg. Timeline Photos.

The Closing Ceremonies for the 2016 games takes place tomorrow. Millions of viewers from around the globe took to the Internet to watch many of this year’s events live. We want to hear from you! Which events did you stream from this year’s games? Share in the comments below. Timeline Photos.
With the closing ceremonies around the corner and the final events wrapping up, take a look at which event had the highest online video traffic peak: http://akamai.me/2bttv8C. Timeline Photos.

When it comes to the world’s biggest sports event, more people than ever are watching online. Our own Ben Bloom and Joachim Hengge share their thoughts in Sports Video Group: http://akamai.me/2aZqql5. Timeline Photos.
"Like" if you'll be watching the men's beach volleyball semifinals today! See how the live streaming traffic looks here: http://akamai.me/2bttv8C. Timeline Photos.

Sports Video Group shares how you can keep up with the latest viewership numbers for the 2016 games in this article: http://akamai.me/2aKm3EP. What do you think? Will this be the most-watched online event in history? Timeline Photos.

Were you watching last weekend’s Portugal-France championship match of the quadrennial European football tournament? So was the rest of the world! Traffic peaked during the match’s overtime period at 7.3 Tbps, which tops the former live sports streaming record of 7.0 Tbps generated during the 2014 World Cup. See more data here: http://akamai.me/29Gt9wQ. Timeline Photos.

Akamai observed a spike in Media & Entertainment traffic being delivered to users in Venezuela, starting approximately one hour after the death of Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez. We believe the spike coincides with the announcement of Chavez's death. Timeline Photos.

According to Akamai's Real-Time Web Monitor, attack traffic was up almost 70% of normal around 6:30 PT on February 19, 2013. Attack Traffic Increases.
Attack traffic increased almost 70% of normal on Feb 19 around 6:30 PT, with a concentration around the Asia Pacific Region. Attack Traffic Increases.

Earlier this morning, Akamai saw a significant spike in customer traffic classified as "Media & Entertainment/Publishing" being delivered to users in Russia.  We believe that this is related to the meteor strike that occurred at 3:20am GMT.  Note that the spikes shown in the graphs occur approximately four hours after the event - we believe that this is when the first international coverage of the event, including news articles and videos, began to appear.  As shown in the graph, traffic levels remained higher than normal after the spikes occurred, presumably due to ongoing interest in the event. Untitled Album.

The Defense Information Systems Agency has recently announced our contract as a provider of web distribution services.  As FCW published last week:

"The new contract will help DISA begin to transition from the existing method of Web content delivery...to a system that uses a unified platform, DISA's Terrace McCaa told FCW June 4 on the sidelines of Akamai's Government Innovation Forum in Washington, D.C. The agency is still working out the requirements and funding for the new system, dubbed the Universal Content Delivery Service, said McCaa, DISA's team lead for GCDS."

We look forward to working with the DISA to securely deliver content from the department. DISA redoing content delivery -- FCW. The Defense Information Systems Agency is exploring the next version of its Global Content Delivery Service.

"Happy Holidays" to you and yours from all of us here at Akamai! All of us here at Akamai are happy and proud to be celebrating the company's 15th anniversary today! We're incredibly proud to share the news that we've been recognized as one of the "Best Companies to Work For" in the Costa Rica, Central America and Caribbean region by the Great Places to Work Institute.

 #MyAkamai. Timeline Photos.

One of the biggest concerns in front-end web optimization is getting pixels in front of the user as quickly as possible. At this Meetup, we're going to take a closer look at how the browser renders images on the page (the "render chain"), how it relates to a standard waterfall chart, and what you can do to make sure that the browser can draw pages as quickly as possible.

You're invited to attend this Meetup in Cambridge on Tuesday, August 13, at 6:30pm, led by Akamai's Matt Ringel and Joseph Morrissey. To RSVP, visit: http://bit.ly/15rhQ18. Matt Ringel and Joseph Morrissey - The Render Chain and You (at Akamai) -  Boston Web Performance Gr. Cyber Monday 9PM Purchasing Peak 104% Above Black Friday. Cyber Monday 9PM Purchasing Peak 104% Above Black Friday - The Akamai Blog.
Cyber Monday Purchasing Activity beat Black Friday by 49% Cyber Monday Purchasing Activity beat Black Friday by 49% - The Akamai Blog.
Thanksgiving & Black Friday Traffic Images. 2012 Holiday Traffic.
Cyber Monday Breaks New Traffic Records. Cyber Monday Breaks New Traffic Records - The Akamai Blog.

Cyber Monday Purchase Behavior Projections. Cyber Monday Purchase Behavior Projections - The Akamai Blog. In addition to shopping behaviors, our Commerce Strategist, Lelah Manz, is reporting an 11:00AM EST peak in traffic, higher than any other point over the holiday weekend at 7,758,804 page views per minute. In Cyber Monday Set To Be Biggest Test Yet, Manz goes into a deeper dive on what Akamai is see...

Cyber Monday Set to Be Biggest Test Yet.  As of 11:00AM ET, Cyber Monday is surging ahead in both peak traffic and volume.  We're already peaking higher than at any other point this holiday weekend at 7,758,804 page views per minute. Cyber Monday Set to Be Biggest Test Yet - The Akamai Blog.

Huge Traffic Volumes on Black Friday - catch the full recap of the day on the Akamai blog. Huge Traffic Volumes on Black Friday - The Akamai Blog. It was a strong Black Friday online by all accounts.  IBM is reporting that sales on the day grew nearly 20% over last year. Black Friday also drove huge volumes of traffic, averaging over 6.3 million page views from 10AM Eastern through to the end of the night.   As expected, peak traffic levels hi...

Black Friday tends to drive much higher peaks earlier in the day because of research activity for offline shopping in the morning hours. Last year on Black Friday we reached peak by 11:00 AM ET, and in 2010 we hit peak by 1:00 PM ET. Strong Start to Black Friday - The Akamai Blog.

Thanksgiving was a blow out traffic day.   With an early peak of 4,910,674 page views per minute at noon ET, the day finished up with a peak of 7,411,734 PV/Min at 10:00 PM, much higher than the early day projections of ~6.2 million page views per minute. Another Hockey Stick Thanksgiving - The Akamai Blog.

What's more important to consumers: Turkey or Shopping? Akamai's Advertising Decision Solutions (ADS) shares a Thanksgiving cornucopia of behavioral shopping data... What's more important to consumers: Turkey or Shopping?   - The Akamai Blog. While mentions of the Mayflower and Plymouth Rock have been few and far between, one thing's for sure, I cannot even begin to count the number of times I've heard "online shopping data," "peak traffic," "Black Friday" or "Cyber Monday" over the past few weeks.  .

clusters.summary: Earlier this week, we celebrated International Women's Day at our offices around the world! Today we celebrated the opening of our new office at 1 Kendall Square with some delicious muffins from Gingerbread Construction Company! Responsive Web Design is quickly becoming the standard way any organization should tackle the post-iPhone web. The client-side approach it embraces makes adapting to the current device easy -- and makes it just as easy to make your site painfully slow.

This Wednesday at 1PM ET, join Akamai's Guy Podjarny and Forrester's Mark Grannan for the webinar, "Overcoming Mobile Performance Challenges in Responsive Web Design." 

You'll learn how to ensure that your responsive site not only looks good, but performs well, too. 

Register for this webinar here:  http://bit.ly/1spM3GX. Overcoming Mobile Performance Challenges in Responsive Web Design. Responsive Web Design can unlock the potential of your site with content tailored to fit multiple device types and browsing environments.

Download this whitepaper today:  http://bit.ly/1h0mUfz. How to Deliver Faster Responsive Web Design Sites. Did you know that 50% of mobile users are unlikely to visit a website again if they are dissatisfied with the website performance during their first visit?

While powerful, Responsive Web Design (RWD) brings with it a set of performance concerns. In this video, Guy Podjarny explains what RWD is and - more importantly - how to understand and avoid the performance concerns it entails. Watch:  http://bit.ly/LjZ8DP. Responsive Web Design & its Performance Pitfalls - The Akamai Blog. Responsive Web Design & its Performance Pitfalls.

Did you know when mobile users are dissatisfied with website performance, 50% are unlikely to visit the site again? Responsive web design (RWD) is an approach gaining traction for enabling easy accessibility on any type of device. RWD depends upon client side device detection and content adaptation. 

Join Akamai's Web Performance CTO, Guy Podjarny, and special guest Peter Sheldon, Principal Analyst at Forrester Research for a live webinar to discuss the challenges of responsive web design. 

To attend this live webinar on Wednesday, July 17 at 1:00 pm EDT, register here: http://bit.ly/12jveAT. Figure 37 illustrates mobile browser usage by users identified to be on cellular networks in the fourth quarter of 2014. See more charts and graphs like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet Report, which is available for download here: http://akamai.me/1FijK8K. Timeline Photos.

In Q3 2014, South Korea remained firmly entrenched in its position as the country in the Asia Pacific region (and the world) with the highest average connection speed, improving by 2.7% QoQ to reach 25.3 Mbps. See more stats like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet report, which you can download here: http://akamai.me/17n5D3k. Timeline Photos.

In the second quarter of 2014, Arkansas had the lowest 4K readiness rate...at just 7.7%. See more stats like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet Report, which is available for download here: http://akamai.me/1zf2URH. Timeline Photos.

Fast Fact: In the second quarter of 2014, South Korea had the highest level of 4K readiness...at 62%. Get more stats like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet Report, which is available for download here: http://akamai.me/1FZE3WR. Timeline Photos.

In the second quarter of 2014, South Korea continued to creep towards complete broadband adoption, growing 1.0% to 95% broadband adoption. Small quarterly increases were also seen in Hong Kong and Japan, as seen in Figure 30. See more stats like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet Report, which you can download here: http://bit.ly/1rr4f1o. Timeline Photos.

As shown in this figure, in Q2 2014, Uruguay maintained its solid lead ahead of the United States, with an average peak connection speed just shy of 50 Mbps. However, the United States and Canada were not too far behind, both with average peak speeds above 40 Mbps, and well ahead of the remaining surveyed countries in the region. See more stats like this in the latest edition of our State of the Internet report, which you can download here:  http://bit.ly/1nGuk1V. Timeline Photos.

Malicious bots can be part of a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack or efforts to extract valuable customer data, or both.

According to our Security Intelligence Response Team, only 2 percent of DDoS attacks use five or more different attack vectors. This one used six and peaked at 363 Gbps. Read about the attack from CSO http://akamai.me/2a8VN8S.

Are bots muddying your analytics? Bots can contribute up to 30-40 percent of a site’s traffic and significantly skew valuable marketing data. Our Global Industry Marketing Manager for Commerce, Caley Iandiorio, elaborates in his latest blog post:  http://akamai.me/29y36by. Are bots muddying your marketing analytics? Bots have become a hot topic with many retailers lately as security has become a higher priority. Malicious bots can be part of a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack or efforts to extract valuable customer data, or both.

Security Threats + DDoS Attacks in Tech? Plan. Don't Panic. With the Akamai network carrying one-third of the world's web traffic, we have unparalleled visibility into the increase in Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks.

DDoS protection needs to confront unexpected sources of attacks, like RIPv1, now used only in unsuspecting homes and offices, which is now being employed to launch sizable DDoS attacks against individual users. A cybersecurity threat advisory on Shellshock (Bash bug) DDoS botnet activity is available from Akamai. The advisory alerts enterprises to a DDoS botnet-building operation by attackers taking advantage of the Bash bug in Linux-based, Mac OS X and Cygwin systems. Enterprises that fail to take action may have their systems compromised by these botnet builders. Malicious actors may use compromised systems to propagate the botnet, launch DDoS attacks, exfiltrate confidential data and run programs on behalf of attackers.
